comments.commentBody: Dear many commenters: I don't think the author is devaluing her role in the relationship by writing this ode to her husband.  It is simply a beautiful and moving gift to her husband.
Your response to Amy is simply and obviously true.  But it is out of place.  She is trying in this beautiful piece to put the focus on her wonderful husband.  Please let her succeed.
I cried when I read this.  So much love.   So much love.
Please stop pushing medical "miracles" on those who may not want the punishing treatments to continue. Conceit at its most damaging.

Everything in this piece talks of how he can support a family: the love of their children, the compilation of so many small gestures of love that add up to something huge - gum balls, and smiley faces by the coffee maker, and grocery shopping, and cooking dinner. But if you're looking for the cashola, I assume that 9-5 job lawyering would do just fine. This piece was one of the most gracious I have read in a very long time. Your comment did not do it justice.

Jason has been married for all of his adult life to a woman he obviously loved enormously and with whom he was happy and shared a great deal and with whom he had children.  His children are gone, his wife is about to be gone.  He will be lonely; deeply lonely.  If he can find someone to share his life ... without trying to make her a substitute for the wife he has lost ... he will be much happier.  And judging from what his wife says, the woman he finds will be happy as well.  It may not be easy ... but it will be easier if sooner rather than later.  (Statistics suggest that widowers who do not remarry soon tend not to remarry at all.)

Dear Amy
Oh my. What an amazingly loving, understanding and generous person you are to have written this article. To be honest, I doubt anyone will ever fill the huge gap that you will leave in Jason's and your childrens' lives.
I have to say now how I hate cancer and are you absolutely sure that this is the end for you? Sorry to ask that but being the optimistic person that I am, I do believe in miracles.
I have never read any of your books but will now make a point of reading them especially the childrens' ones as reading has been and is very dear and special in mine and my childrens' lives.
May you spend the rest of your days surrounded by your wonderful husband and children. How precious those moments will be to you all.
Sending love, light and gratitude for having read this wonderful article which once again reminded me of the preciousness of every moment we spend with those we love x

Dear Amy,

The comments by so many readers are as moving as your essay. And here I always assumed that Prince Charming only existed in fairy tales. Your beautiful writing and wonderful tribute to Jason has prompted me to purchase all of your books, one each month, so I can elongate the enjoyment and enrichment your words bring.

I firmly believe the strong omnipotent relationship you and Jason have will carry and sustain him through the coming days, months and years. You have not only given your husband such an incredible gift of this article, you have also shared and given so many readers reasons to be thankful and appreciative of our spouses. I do not think there is one reader who will ever take their spouse for granted again. Thank you for this unforgettable reminder.

Peace, love and many blessings to you and your family.
I've been a caregiver spouse to my wife who is a 13-year-plus stroke survivor. You just made a bad day better. Thanks.
Hang in there, Doug.  You are appreciated, even if you don't hear it enough. I know I appreciate my ex's love & care, but too late for me.
Stop with the miracles exhortations. She is on her own path. Respect it.

People who did not "work hard enough" as defined by Republicans, will not be able to afford the insurance premiums.  What are people going to do when the Republicans start reducing medicare and medicaid in the coming years?  If a 65 year old had to buy health insurance today, I bet it would cost at least $2000 a month per person.  This is why LBJ created medicare and medicaid, because senior citizens and the poor could not afford the insurance.  Sad, sad.

A single truth: people die, we, every one of the readers, die without a remotely such beautiful confession to make like yours. I recently lost a 14-year old romance. No she didn't die, but found the new path/person. Yes I wished her best. Like a man. Only if you could see how something constantly dying in your heart is far worse than leaving but staying forever. I envy you: you completed your love (by making this confession), having happily married years not only to yourselves but to three kids now grown up to be married. Family is a divine invention. We know it. We all come from there. What a full life that was and is and going to be; you have achieved a family and prospered, maybe it's time to find the heavenly family. Gladly. Now you can consider this my confession.
Beautiful soul. Carpe Diem my friend and live it to the fullest.

"the only solution to the crisis would be a carefully executed coup that removes the regime from power without triggering a nuclear launch"?

Mind-boggling assertion. What could possibly go wrong. right?

Especially after all the successes of all "carefully executed coups" in the last 10+ years

I propose a different strategy. Blanket the Nth Korea with packages of beef jerky and Oreo cookies with notes saying the American people wish you no harm.  repeat monthly with other treats and messages of good will and explaining the fruits of freedom.

What, are you trying to kill them? Processed meat and sugar? Only kidding, actually I like your idea a lot better than bombs, which is where I think this is headed.

North Korea is dark at night, South Korea is alive with light. Can't these folks figure out a way to get along with the South? Can't they see that the booming economy to the South is better than their militarism? Wouldn't they like to join their countrymen to the South as well as the rest of the world?

This world grows smaller each year. We all need to make it work. People like Kim Jong-un are throwbacks to a different era.

Brilliant thinking! How about some Peter Pan peanut butter and loaves of multigrain, as well... Oh, and let's not forget rose petals. Lots and lots of rose petals. And maybe just a gentle sprinkling of pixie dust. That ought to prove to them that they do are not the only inhabitants of the loonyverse...
Great, as long as you disregard North Korea's massive anti-aircraft defenses. Old? Sure. A bit rusty? You bet. Not worth risking it for a load of beef jerky? Definitely!
Sadly, I have to agree.  And those of us living on Pacific Islands are watching the advancements in the NK offensive nuclear program with increasing concern...

Richard: Thanks for taking the time to read and to respond to my observation. You speak of tunnels. When I was in South Korea summer of 2015, I visited the DMZ and was able to tour an invasion tunnel dug by North Korea. The link below shows the path created by the South to reach the invasion tunnel.
https://www.flickr.com/photos/stevebrown1/19490191614/in/album-721576541...

Gwe,

The reason for the North's existence and its creation in the first place can be explained in one word "China". China is in a worse position with the North than are we. What seemed a good idea in the '50s is looking worse and worse as the North builds more Nukes right next door to China.

The North is exactly the same country it was in 1950. China is nothing like the same country. There is evidence that China has had enough and is just waiting for something really bad to happen. Something "really bad will still leave legions of the dead however.

There is lots of blame to go around and it is likely that there was no military solution to the problem in the '50's short of WW3 with Nukes on all sides.

Yes I'm sure Pres Trump will bring to bear his experience in building golf courses and gilt palaces and come up with an easy and simple strategy that no one before was able to, and solve the problem with a series of tweets.
Maybe trump released that so everyone understands him whining for no solution cause its such a complex thing for him ?..
I lost the love of my life at 51 and couldn't agree more.
Why, yes, I may want to marry your husband! If I weren't married to the love if my life already, that is. Yours is a wonderful story and it's not over yet. Where there is life there is love.

Dear Amy, I've often told my brothers and male friends, in answer to their question, "what do women want"?: Two things. Women want to be shown that they are loved. And, they want to be shown that every day. Your Jason did that for you, and it seems that you also returned that love and respect. My heart breaks for your family's loss and pain, but I know that you will leave behind the powerful gift of memory of your love for them.

Every person has his or her own path. Don't judge the extent of someone's love for another by the length of time that person appears to grieve the loss. Believe me, that sense of loss never leaves you, no matter what your next chapter holds.
Even if he does "rush" into something, I hope his choices aren't judged as harshly as that word implies.
